CLUE: With hand below the shoulder (of bowling or serving)
OUTPUT: ["Bowler's Stance - The position assumed by a person about to roll a bowling ball, with hands placed under the shoulders.", 'Serving Position - In tennis and table tennis, players often adopt a stance where one hand is below shoulder height as they prepare to serve.', 'Delivery Arm - This refers to the arm that moves forward during a serving motion or while releasing a bowling ball.', 'Release Hand - The hand used for releasing an object, such as a bowling ball, in front of and below shoulder level.', "Grip Hold - A position where one's grip on an implement (e.g., racket or ball) is held with the hand under the shoulders.", 'Hand Placement - The act of placing hands at a specific location; for bowling, it refers to keeping hands beneath the shoulders during setup.', "Thrower's Grip - A gripping style used by throwers (e.g., in shot put or discus) where one hand is positioned below shoulder height.", 'Shot Put Handle Hold - In shot put, athletes hold the implement with their dominant hand underneath and at a comfortable level near their shoulders.', 'Ball Carrier Stance - A stance in sports like bowling or cricket where one hand supports the ball beneath shoulder height during delivery.', "Overhead Hand Position - In volleyball, this refers to players holding the ball above their heads with a hand placed underneath the other arm's shoulder level.", "Pitcher's Grip - In baseball, when preparing for a pitch, the throwing hand is placed beneath and below shoulder height.", "Serve Reach - The reach of an athlete's serving arm or bowling arm during delivery; typically just above shoulder level.", "Bowler's Block Position - When setting up to throw a bowling ball, the hand position is underneath and slightly forward of the shoulders (blocking).", "Catcher's Grip - In baseball, while holding onto a caught ball, the catcher may have one hand below shoulder level for better control.", 'Reception Hand - The hand used to receive or grab an object; in some sports, it is placed beneath and near the shoulders during execution.', "Tossing Stance - In various activities (e.g., serving a volleyball), this refers to the stance where one's throwing arm starts below shoulder height before release.", 'Golf Swing Preparation - During golf, players often adopt an over-the-top grip or cross-body backswing with their hands underneath and near shoulder level.', "Bowler's Setup Posture - The posture a bowler assumes when preparing to deliver the ball; includes positioning one hand beneath and slightly forward of the shoulders.", 'Defensive Stance (Basketball) - In basketball, this is a defensive stance where players have their hands under and near shoulder height for better control.', 'Paddle Hand Position - While playing paddle sports like table tennis or racquetball, one hand may be placed below the shoulders to facilitate quick arm movements.']

their dress might sometimes reflect cross-dressing)', 'Enby (short for "enby", a term used to describe non-binary individuals, often includes cross-dressing as part of self-expression)', 'Agender (an individual who does not identify with any gender; ['Sketch - To outline or draw something in pencil, on paper or other surface.', 'Render - To produce an image or visual representation using lines and colors.', 'Illustrate - To explain or make clear by using examples, pictures, or diagrams.', 'Draft - A preliminary version of a piece of writing or artwork that may be revised later.', 'Outline - A line drawing showing the edges of an object or figure.', 'Penciled - Done with a pencil; lightly drawn by using graphite on paper.', 'Painted - Applied paint to create an image, typically done with brushes and various mediums.', 'Caricature - A drawing of a person or thing in which certain features are exaggerated for comedic effect.', 'Etching - An engraving technique used to create designs on metal plates by acid.', 'Engrave - To cut or carve a design onto a hard surface, such as glass, wood, or metal.', 'Crayon - A stick made of colored wax used for drawing pictures by children.', 'Chalk - Soft, white, porous stone used as a writing implement, typically in black markings on chalkboards.', 'Stippling - Creating an image with small dots or marks to form shading and texture.', 'Cross-hatching - A drawing technique that involves layering intersecting sets of parallel lines to create tonal or shaded effects.', 'Collage - An artwork created by assembling different materials, such as paper cutouts, onto a surface.', 'Fresco - A mural painting technique in which water-based pigments are applied on freshly laid wet plaster.', 'Charcoal - A form of carbon derived from wood used for drawing and sketching.', "Brushstroke - The visible mark left by a brush during the act of painting, often conveying an artist's style or emotion.", 'Blending - Smoothing out color transitions in a drawing to create a seamless effect.', 'Calligraphy - The art of beautiful handwriting formed with a pen or brush and used for decorative purposes, often seen in illustrations and invitations.']

['Indifference - The lack of interest, concern or sympathy towards something.', 'Apathy - Lack of enthusiasm or interest in activities or things typically considered enjoyable or important.', 'Nonchalance - Casual or indifferent attitude; coolness, composure, or indifference.', 'Disinterest - Failure to give importance or attention to something that would otherwise matter.', "Apathy - Indifference towards others' emotions and feelings.", 'Aloofness - Emotional detachment from situations or people around you.', 'Detached - Not attached, connected or involved with someone or something emotionally.', 'Unconcerned - Lack of worry or interest in a particular matter or situation.', 'Dispassionate - Showing no passion; unemotional and rational.', 'Remote - Distant physically, emotionally or mentally from something important.', "Unfeeling - Not showing sympathy or concern for others' emotions or feelings.", 'Coolness - Indifference or lack of interest in a situation.', 'Nonreactive - Not responsive to stimuli; unresponsive emotionally.', 'Impassivity - Lacking passion, enthusiasm, or feeling towards something.', 'Insouciance - Heedlessness, carefree attitude with little regard for consequences.', 'Distant - Separated by space, time, or emotion from something important.', 'Unresponsive - Not reacting to stimuli; indifferent or disinterested in a particular matter.', 'Inattentiveness - Lack of attention given to something that requires focus and care.', 'Dispassionate - Showing no interest, emotion, or passion towards something.', 'Stoicism - The ability to endure pain or hardship without the display of feelings or complaints.']

['Remorse - A deep, painful feeling of guilt or regret for wrongdoing.', 'Contrition - Deep sorrow and guilt over having done something wrong.', 'Penitence - The state of being penitent; repentance accompanied by sincere regret or humility.', 'Wistfulness - A feeling of longing or melancholy, often associated with missed opportunities or past mistakes.', 'Mourning - Deep sorrow and grief over something that has been lost or a mistake made in the past.', 'Regretfulness - The state of being filled with regret; having strong feelings of disappointment about a situation or action taken in the past.', 'Lamentation - Expression of grief, mourning, or regret for an unfortunate event that has occurred.', 'Melancholy - A feeling of pensive sadness, often associated with reflection on past mistakes or decisions.', 'Disappointment - Feeling let down or unsatisfied by something; can stem from regretting choices made in the past.', "Sullenness - An appearance of gloominess and a tendency to be regretful about one's actions, often expressed through grumpy behavior.", 'Grief - Deep sorrow or distress caused by loss or sadness; can also refer to feeling regret for what could have been in the past.', 'Apology - An expression of regret or remorse for an action taken, often involving a request for forgiveness.', "Repentance - The act of expressing sincere regret and remorse for wrongdoing; acknowledgment of one's mistake with the intention to change behavior in the future.", 'Wrathfulness - An intense feeling or display of anger, often associated with strong emotions surrounding past mistakes or transgressions.', 'Sorrow - A feeling of deep distress or sadness, which can stem from regret over something that has happened in the past.', 'Disillusionment - The state of being disappointed by finding out that someone or something is not as good as one thought; it may arise from realizing mistakes made due to false beliefs or assumptions.', 'Nostalgia - A sentimental longing for the past, often associated with regret over what could have been different.', 'Lamentation - The act of expressing grief or sorrow, which can include feelings of deep regret about a situation or decision made in the past.', "Discontentment - Feeling unsatisfied or dissatisfied with one's current circumstances; this feeling may arise from regretting previous choices that led to present disappointments.", 'Sorrowfulness - A state of being filled with sorrow, which can include deep regret for past actions or decisions made.']

['Swindle - To deceive or defraud someone for personal gain.', 'Shuffle - To rearrange or manipulate something, typically money or resources, unfairly.', 'Concoct - To create (a plan, scheme, or story) especially with fraudulent intent.', "Embezzle - To steal or misappropriate funds entrusted to one's care.", 'Hustle - A sly and deceitful way of making money.', 'Chisel - To cheat, defraud, or swindle by using clever tactics.', 'Rig - To manipulate a system for personal gain.', 'Trick - To use cunning or deceptive methods to achieve an advantage.', 'Cleverly - Using intelligence and ingenuity in dishonest ways.', 'Cheat - To act unfairly, deceitfully, or falsely for personal gain.', "Chicanery - The use of deceptive practices to achieve one's goals.", 'Gambit - A strategy used in games, but can also refer to a risky scheme or plan that involves dishonest means.', 'Scam - A fraudulent scheme designed to cheat people out of money.', 'Shell Game - An illegal gambling game involving deception and sleight-of-hand, but can also refer to any con trick or scam.', 'Bend the Rules - To manipulate rules or systems in an unfair manner for personal gain.', 'Wrap Up Loans - A colloquial term referring to the illegal practice of lending money and then claiming that it was never legally granted (e.g., payday loans).', 'Hoodwink - To deceive or trick someone, often by using dishonest means.', 'Backhanded Compliment - A seemingly positive remark with a hidden critical or insulting message', "Cut Corners - To act dishonestly or use shortcuts to achieve a goal at the expense of others' interests.", "Puff Up - A slang term for exaggerating one's achievements or abilities, often in an attempt to deceive or mislead others about oneself."]

['Novel - A fictional prose narrative typically longer than a short story and often published in book form.', 'Chapter - A section or division within a book containing a specific amount of content.', "Page - The rectangular sheets that make up the bulk of printed material, usually bound together inside a book's cover.", 'Paragraph - A distinct section of writing typically dealing with a single theme and indicated by a new line or indentation.', 'Plot - The sequence of events that comprise a story in a novel, play, movie, etc.', 'Protagonist - The main character around whom the plot revolves.', 'Antagonist - A character that opposes the protagonist and creates conflict within the narrative.', "Verse/Verse Poetry - A poem or a series of poems, each constituting one 'verse.'", 'Epilogue - The concluding section at the end of a book or play in which the author provides closure for certain plotlines and characters.', 'Foreshadowing - An indication that suggests what is going to happen later in the story.', 'Symbolism - Using symbols, like objects, characters, figures, or colors, to represent ideas and qualities beyond their literal meaning.', 'Metapmuny - A figure of speech involving a comparison between two things not alike but having something in common.', 'Alliteration - The repetition of initial consonant sounds in closely positioned words or syllables within lines of verse or prose.', 'Allegory - A narrative that can be interpreted to reveal a hidden meaning, typically moral or political.', 'Morality - Principles concerning the distinction between right and wrong behavior; it is often discussed in books with strong ethical themes.', "Biography - An account of someone's life written by someone else.", "Autobiography - A self-written account of one's own life, usually chronicling the author’s experiences and accomplishments.", 'Fable - A short fictional story (usually with animals as characters) conveying a moral.', 'Folklore - The traditional beliefs, customs, stories, songs, and dances of a culture, passed through generations by word of mouth.', 'Anthology - A published collection of poems or other pieces of writing, usually by various authors.']

['Zeelandic - Related to or originating from Zeeland, which is connected with the sea sharing its name', "Schelde - The major river flowing into the North Sea in Belgium and the Netherlands; also a part of Zeeland's maritime history", 'Zuyderzee - Historical region around the present-day IJmeer (IJsselmeer) lake, once known as a sea before being reclaimed', 'Vlaamse Zee - Dutch name for Belgian coastal waters near the North Sea', 'Hollandic - Pertaining to the provinces of South Holland and North Holland in the Netherlands; the southern part borders the North Sea', 'Hollands Zee - Refers specifically to the western part of the North Sea that lies along the coast of the Dutch province of Zeeland', 'Zandkreek - A former lake area within the modern IJmeer, previously considered a sea', 'Vlaamse Hollandse Zee - Historical term for Belgian waters near the Netherlands in the North Sea', 'Waddenzee - The shoreline of islands and shoals known as the Wadden Sea, an intertidal area separating land from the open sea along the coasts of Denmark, Germany, and the Netherlands', 'Zeelandic Flanders - A region in Belgium that borders the North Sea to its southwest', 'Zijl - Dutch for "eye," used colloquially as a metaprompt name but associated with historical seafaring around the North Sea', 'Westerschelde - One of two major estuaries in Zeeland, Netherlands; part of the North Sea watershed', 'Easterschelde - The other primary estuary in Zeeland, which also contributes to the North Sea maritime context', "Waddenzee - Another term for the Wadden Sea that connects multiple countries' shorelines with the North Sea", "Noorderkwartier - A Dutch term referring to the northern quarter of a region, historically related to the North Sea's maritime influence in areas like Zeeland", "Zuiderzee - Historically known as a large embayment or bay on the northwest coast of Europe that partly existed before becoming today's IJmeer lake due to land reclamation efforts", 'Zuid-Hollandsche Zee - Dutch term referring to the waters off South Holland, part of which includes areas around the North Sea', "West-Vlaamse Zee - A historical name for Belgian coastal waters in relation to the North Sea's influence", 'Oosterscheldekering - The significant storm surge barrier that protects parts of the Waddenzee and IJmeer, reflecting its connection with the sea named after a Dutch navigator (Dutch for "Eastern Scheldt Barrier")', 'Zeelanden - A collective term referring to areas associated with or named after the North Sea in the context of Dutch history and exploration']

['Timepiece - A device used to measure and display time, such as watches or clocks.', 'Chronometer - An accurate instrument designed for measuring time precisely, often used in scientific experiments.', 'Tick-tock - The regular sounds produced by a clock or similar timekeeping device.', 'Second hand - A moving indicator on an analogue clock that shows the passing seconds.', 'Stopwatch - A handheld timing device used to measure elapsed time with high accuracy, commonly used in sports and athletics.', 'Pendulum - The swinging motion of a pendulum, which is part of many traditional mechanical clocks.', 'Timekeeper - An official person responsible for keeping track of the time during events or competitions.', 'Hourglass - A device with two glass bulbs connected by narrow neck that measures and indicates the passage of time through sand falling from one bulb to another.', 'Sundial - An ancient timekeeping device consisting of a flat plate marked with hour lines and an upright gnomon (a stick or pointer) used for measuring solar time.', 'Quartz watch - A type of electronic watch that uses the piezoelectric properties of quartz crystals to measure time accurately.', 'Water clock - An ancient hydraulic device that measures and displays time by regulating water flow through a vessel with calibrated openings.', 'Digital watch - A modern electronic watch displaying time in numerical format, often accompanied by additional functions like alarm or stopwatch.', "Cuckoo clock - A traditional German-style clock featuring mechanical cuckoos that emerge from their nests to announce the hour with a bird's song.", 'Time flies - An idiomatic expression emphasizing how quickly time passes by, often used in casual conversation or storytelling.', 'Countdown - A gradual reduction of numbers leading up to an event or deadline; also refers to the decreasing seconds before a rocket launch.', 'Minute hand - The longer hand on an analogue clock that indicates minutes past each hour.', 'Stopwatch timer - An electronic device used to measure elapsed time with high precision, often in competitive sports or scientific experiments.', 'Atomic clock - A highly accurate type of clock based on atomic vibrations and transitions; these are the most precise timekeeping devices currently available.', 'Hoursglass timer - Similar to a traditional hourglass, used for measuring short periods of time in various settings like cooking or games.', 'Tick-tock clock - An expression referring to the sound produced by mechanical clocks, often used in literature and popular culture to represent passing time.']

['Cherry - A fruit tree belonging to the genus Prunus, known for its sweet cherries with pitted flesh and distinctive red or black drupe-like fruits.', 'Peach - Another member of the genus Prunus, characterized by its fuzzy skin covering a succulent, juicy fruit that can be yellow or white inside when ripe.', 'Plum (Prunus domestica) - A deciduous tree in the family Rosaceae, known for its edible stone-fruit with a single large seed encased within a fleshy outer layer.', "Almond (Prunus dulcis) - Though technically a drupe, almonds are often referred to as nut-like because of their culinary uses; the tree's fruit is enclosed by an inedible shell that splits open at maturity.", 'Apricot (Prunus armeniaca) - Similar to cherries and peaches, this small deciduous tree produces a fuzzy-skinned, smooth-fleshed stone fruit with a tart flavor when ripe.', 'Damson (Prunus domestica subsp', 'Quince (Cydonia oblonga) - Native to Western Asia and South Caucasus regions, this tree yields a large, pome-like fruit with rough texture and a high concentration of seeds.', 'Medlar (Mespilus germanica) – A small shrub or spindly deciduous tree whose fruits are similar in structure to apples but ripen by exposure to frosts and develop a honey-like consistency when softened through sun-drying or stewing.', 'Mulberry (Morus spp.) – A genus of trees within the family Moraceae, producing an abundance of small drupes that are commonly eaten fresh or used for dyes in silk production.', 'Blackthorn (Prunus spinosa) - Known also as sloe, this spiny shrub yields small black fruits often preserved in jams and liquors due to their high pectin content and bitter taste.']

['Catcher - In baseball, the catcher is responsible for receiving pitches and "netting" the ball with their mitts.', 'Goalkeeper - The primary defender in soccer or hockey, tasked with preventing opponents from scoring by blocking shots on goal.', "Saves - A statistic used primarily in ice hockey to describe a goaltender's success at stopping the puck from entering the net.", 'Hooker - In rugby, this position often refers to the scrum-half or loosehead prop who assists with ball recovery and distribution.', 'Netminder - A term used interchangeably for goalkeepers in ice hockey and soccer/football contexts.', 'Dibberman - Combining "dipper" (a slang term for catcher) and "Bowman," this nickname is sometimes given to baseball catchers.', "Cushionist - In handball, a player who prevents the ball from passing into the opponent's goal by positioning their body or equipment strategically.", 'Goalie - A general term used for any person responsible for protecting the goal in various sports such as soccer, hockey, and lacrosse.', "Net-binder - In netball, a player whose primary responsibility is to catch passes and direct the ball into the opponent's goal circle.", "Goal guardian - Another term for a goaltender in ice hockey or football, emphasizing their role as defenders of the team's goals.", 'Net-taker - A more general description of someone who catches and prevents the ball from going into a specific area (net).', 'Ball-hunter - This term can apply to any player in sports that require retrieving or "netting" balls, such as basketball free throws or soccer throw-ins.', "Blocker - While not exclusively related to nets, this role involves defending against opponents' shots by positioning themselves between the ball and the net.", 'Goalkeeper dog handler - In some sports like hunting with hounds, handlers assist in retrieving balls or game animals that might otherwise end up near a goal area.', 'Ball-catcher - A generic term for someone whose primary task is to catch balls during play, regardless of sport.', 'Net saver - Refers to players who successfully prevent the ball from scoring by positioning themselves in front of nets (like in hockey or lacrosse).', "Catching center - In volleyball, a player's primary responsibility is to catch and control incoming balls during play.", 'Net protector - A term used for players whose main task is defending the goal area from opponents trying to score by shooting or throwing the ball into it.', "Goal-guarding midfielder - In soccer, this might refer to a player who often positions themselves near the opposition's net in order to prevent shots on goal.", 'Net interceptor - A term that can apply to players in sports like basketball or volleyball who quickly react and stop balls heading towards the net.']

['Chips - Thin slices or chunks of potato, corn, or other vegetables fried until crisp and seasoned with salt and various flavors.', 'Pretzels - Long, twisted bread products made from dough that is boiled in lye water before baking, often sprinkled with coarse salt.', 'Popcorn - A type of corn kernel that explodes when heated to create a light and fluffy snack.', 'Nachos - Triangular or circular chips made from tortilla chips layered on top of each other and covered with melted cheese, jalapeños, beans, sour cream, and guacamole.', 'Cracker - A small, flat, crispy baked product usually made from flour, water or fat, and seasonings like herbs, garlic powder, and onion powder.', 'Sausage rolls - Filled pastry tubes wrapped in a layer of dough and then baked until golden brown', 'Cheese puffs - Deep-fried or baked balls made from various types of cheeses, often served as an appetizer or snack.', 'Rice cakes - Small flat discs made from rice flour, water, and salt that are steamed and dried to create a light and crispy texture.', 'Veggie sticks - Thinly sliced vegetables like carrots, celery, cucumber or bell pepper served with dips such as hummus or ranch dressing for dipping.', 'Chicken nuggets - Bite-sized pieces of ground chicken meat that have been formed into a shape, breaded or battered, and then deep-fried until golden brown.', 'Beef jerky: A dried form of beef often seasoned with spices like garlic, onion, or black pepper; it is thinly sliced, marinated, and then dehydrated to create a savory snack.', 'Fish sticks - Breaded strips of whitefish that are deep-fried until golden brown and served with tartar sauce.', 'Tortilla chips - Triangular or circular chips made from corn tortillas fried or baked until crisp, often seasoned with salt and various flavors like lime, chili powder, or cumin.', 'Spiced nuts: A variety of snack foods made by roasting different types of nuts (almonds, cashews, peanuts) and mixing them with spices such as cinnamon, cloves, ginger, paprika, or garlic powder.', 'Stuffed olives: Green or black olives filled with a savory filling like capers, anchovies, almonds, or pimentos and then cured in brine or marinated in olive oil.', 'Cheese balls - Small spheres of cheese that have been rolled into shape, often coated in breadcrumbs or paprika for added texture and flavor.', 'Beef skewers: Skewered pieces of ground beef marinated with spices like garlic, onion, cumin, and chili powder, then grilled until cooked through.', 'Taco chips - Small corn tortillas that have been crisped or fried to create a unique texture similar to potato chips but more flavorful due to the presence of cornmeal and lime juice.', 'Bean rounds: Flattened balls made from cooked beans (like black beans, pinto beans, or kidney beans) that have been seasoned with spices like garlic powder, onion powder, chili powder, and sometimes cheese before being fried to create a savory snack.', 'Cheese puffs: Savory baked balls made from various types of cheeses (like mozzareran, cheddar, or gouda) mixed with herbs, spices, or breadcrumbs for added texture and flavor.', 'Zucchini fries: Thinly sliced zucchini sticks that have been breaded and deep-fried until crispy and golden brown, typically served with a side of dipping sauce like ketchup or ranch dressing.', 'Shrimp cocktail - A dish consisting of chilled shrimp served in a tangy cocktail sauce made from ketchup, horseradish, and lemon juice; it is typically presented as an appetizer but can be enjoyed as a savory snack too.', 'Spicy nuts: Nuts (like peanuts, cashews or almonds) that have been mixed with spices like cayenne powder, paprika, or chili flakes and roasted until crispy for an extra kick of heat.', 'Potato skins - Halved baked potatoes filled with a mix of seasoned cheese, bacon bits, green onions, sour cream, or other savory ingredients before being baked again to create a warm and crispy snack.']

['Laureate - A person awarded a prize or honor, typically for academic or artistic achievements.', 'Freeman - In ancient Rome and England, an honorary citizen granted certain privileges and rights by a monarch.', 'Benefactor - A person who provides aid to a religious organization, school, person, or society through generous financial donations.', 'Patron - A wealthy supporter of a cause, artist, institution, or group.', 'Distinguished - Having exceptional and positive qualities; distinguished people are highly respected for their accomplishments.', 'Eminent - Highly ranked or well-known in a particular field, particularly in academics or the arts.', 'Exalted - Raised to high rank, glory, or honor.', 'Esteemed - Respected and admired; highly valued.', 'Illustrious - Famous and respected, often for notable achievements; also conveying a sense of grandeur and beauty.', 'Noble - Having fine personal qualities such as generosity or loyalty that make one worthy of praise; historically associated with high social rank.', 'Venerable - Held in great respect; deserving of veneration due to age, wisdom, or other admirable qualities.', 'Revered - Deeply admired and honored for excellence, achievements, or virtues.', 'Glorious - Producing brilliant radiance; splendid; majestic; impressive and worthy of honor or praise.', "Respected - Held in high esteem by others due to one's character, behavior, or accomplishments.", 'Honorable - Showing fairness, honesty, integrity; deserving of respect and admiration.', 'Distinguished - Set apart from the ordinary; notable and impressive for its excellence or achievements.', 'Accoladed - Awarded with accolades or recognition for outstanding accomplishments in a particular field.', 'Honored - Showing esteem or respect to someone, often by giving an award or distinction.', 'Esteemed - Held in high regard; considered highly and respectfully.', 'Exalted - Immortalized as a deity or held in high esteem due to exceptional qualities or achievements.']
